header.title: 'PC brigade strikes again' Mr Men and Little Miss branded sexist by university study
header.subtitle: POPULAR Mr Men and Little Miss children’s stories have been branded sexist in a new academic research paper, sparking fury online.
header.postText: Roger Hargreaves lovable characters conform to patriarchal gender roles according to the study - with more than half the stories showing a Little Miss being saved.', 'Little Misses were saved in 51.5 per cent of stories, with males saved in just 32.6 per cent of Mr Hargreaves’ tales.', 'Male characters are also found to have more speaking lines in the stories.', 'The University of Lincoln study said: Generally female characters were more passive, had less direct speech and relied on being saved more than male characters.', 'And Lincoln-based researcher Madeleine Pownall concluded that male characters had an average of 12 more words than their female counterparts in the stories.', 'On average, Little Misses had just 53.5 words per story, while males enjoyed 61.5 words.', 'And the study provoked fury online.', 'One Twitter user said: Now Mr Men and Little Miss stories are branded sexist.', 'PC Brigade are really being silly.', 'Steve Thomas said: Go ye looking hard for offence, snowflake…ye will surely find it!', 'Get a grip!', 'Steven Treasures added: Who are these people and why haven’t they got anything better to do?', 'And one Twitter account claimed: If cultural Marxists can’t tear own our statues, they will rubbish our history in every way they can.', 'Even the Mr Men books!', 'The study also sensationally claimed that the series  traditional gender stereotypes do not stop there with character names, like Little Miss Bossy, reinforcing gender roles.', 'The academics suggest that stereotypical passages in the stories confirm their hypothesis too. ', 'In one passage cited, Mr Hargreaves characters say: I know what that naughty little lady needs.', 'Another reads: She managed to find herself the perfect job.', 'She now works for Mr Lazy!She cooks and cleans for him.', 'It is further noted that the series, aimed at children two - years - old and over, published only Mr - stories for the first ten years of their print run. ', ' The first Little Miss book was published in the 1980 s. ', ' 47 Mr Men and 34 Little Miss books, published between 1971 and 2014, were analysed in the study - and the findings were proudly presented at the British Psychological Society’ s annual conference in Nottingham.', 'Egmont, the publisher of Mr Men and Little Miss books, declined to comment.'
